revision.comment: migrating [[Wikipedia:Persondata|Persondata]] to Wikidata, [[toollabs:kasparbot/persondata/|please help]], see [[toollabs:kasparbot/persondata/challenge.php/article/Charles Asten|challenges for this article]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox military person |name=Charles Asten |image= |caption= |birth_date={{Birth date|1834|09|14}} |death_date={{Death date and age|1885|09|14|1834|09|14}} |placeofburial_label= |placeofburial= |birth_place=[[City of Halifax|Halifax, Nova Scotia]] |death_place=Halifax, Nova Scotia |placeofburial_coordinates= <!-- {{Coord|LAT|LONG|display=inline,title}} --> |nickname= |birth_name=Michael Charles Asten |allegiance={{flag|United States}} |branch=[[United States Navy]] |serviceyears= |rank=[[Quarter Gunner]] |servicenumber= |unit= |commands= |battles=[[American Civil War]] * [[Red River Campaign]] |battles_label= |awards=[[Medal of Honor]]<ref name=ArmyMilHist>{{cite web|title=Civil War Medal of Honor Recipients - (A-L)|url=http://www.history.army.mil/html/moh/civwaral.html|publisher=U.S. Army Center of Military History|accessdate=25 December 2010}}</ref> |relations= |laterwork= }} '''Charles Asten''' (born '''Michael Charles Asten''', but served under his middle name)<ref name=Smith>{{cite book|last=Smith|first=Myron J.|title=Tinclads in the Civil War: Union Light-Draught Gunboat Operations on Western Waters, 1862-1865|year=2009|publisher=McFarland|isbn=978-0-7864-3579-1|page=221}}</ref> (September 14, 1834 – September 14, 1885)<ref name=FAGM /> was a Quarter Gunner in the [[United States Navy]] during the [[American Civil War]]. Asten was born in Halifax, [[Nova Scotia]], in September 1834, and he entered the United States Navy in Chicago, Illinois, during the Civil War.<ref name=ArmyMilHist/><ref name=FAGM>{{cite web|title=Michael Charles Asten|url=http://www.findagrave.com/cgi-bin/fg.cgi?page=gr&GRid=7157956|publisher=Find A Grave Memorial|accessdate=22 January 2011}}</ref> In 1864, he served aboard the [[USS Signal (1862)|USS ''Signal'']], a U.S. tinclad,<ref name=Smith /> during the [[Red River Campaign]].<ref name=ArmyMilHist/>
==''Signal'' incident== On May 4, 1864, the USS ''Signal'' was ordered to proceed up the [[Red River of the South|Red River]] with a bearer of dispatches from [[Major general (United States)|Major General]] [[Nathaniel Prentice Banks]],<ref name=DANFS>{{cite web|title=''Signal I''|url=http://www.history.navy.mil/danfs/s12/signal_i.htm|work=Dictionary of American Naval Fighting Ships|publisher=United States Navy|accessdate=22 January 2011}}</ref> the commander of the Union Red River Campaign forces. After traversing about {{convert|20|mi|km}} on the river, the USS ''Signal'' met Confederate forces, and the ensuing conflict, which also involved the [[USS Covington (1863)|USS ''Covington'']] and Army transport ship ''John Warner'', continued into the night.<ref name=DANFS/> On May 5, the ''Signal'' was disabled and the crew, including Asten, reluctantly abandoned the ship; having surrendered, they were captured on land.<ref name=DANFS/>{{Failed verification|date=June 2011}}
==Aftermath== Asten, who had, on May 5, carried out his duties despite being on the sick list, was awarded the [[Medal of Honor]] on December 31, 1864.<ref name=ArmyMilHist/> [[George Butts]], and six other fellow ''Signal'' crew members, also received Medals of Honor for their valor during the action.<ref name=FAGM/>
Charles Asten died on September 14, 1885, in Nova Scotia.<ref name=Smith/> He was interred at [[Saint Francis Cemetery]] in [[Providence County, Rhode Island]].<ref name=FAGM/>
==Full citation== Aster's Medal of Honor citation reads as follows: :"Served on board the U.S.S. Signal, Red River, 5 May 1864. Proceeding up the Red River, the U.S.S. Signal engaged a large force of enemy field batteries and sharpshooters, returning their fire until the Federal ship was totally disabled, at which time the white flag was raised. Although on the sick list, Q.G. Asten courageously carried out his duties during the entire engagement."<ref name=ArmyMilHist/>
==See also== {{Portal|Biography|American Civil War|United States Navy}} *[[List of American Civil War Medal of Honor recipients: A–F|List of American Civil War Medal of Honor recipients]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.cmohs.org/recipient-detail/42/asten-charles.php Congressional Medal of Honor Society page]
